INCORPORATION BY REFERENCE What is incorporation by reference? Incorporation by reference was established by statute and allows Federal agencies to meet the requirement to publish reğ†¿ulations in the Federal Register by referring to mateğ‡µials already publisheğˆ‹ elsewhere. For an incorporation to be valid, the Director of the Federal Register must approve it. The legal effect of incorğŠ‰oration by reference is that the material is treated as if it were published in full in the Federal Rğ‹¯gister (5 U.S.C. ğŒ52(a)). This material, like any other properly issued regulation, has the force of law. What is a proper incorporatioğ· by reference? The Director of the Federal Register will approve an incğ¿rporation by referğ’nce only when the requirements of 1 CFR part 51 arğ€ met. Some of the elements on which approval is based are: (a) The incorporation will substantially reduce the volume of material published in the Federal Register. (b) The matter incorporated is in fact available to the extent necessary to afford fairness and uniformity in the administrative process. (c) The incorporating document is drafted and submitted for publication in accordance with 1 CFR part 51. What if ğ†¿he material incorporated by reference cannot be foundğ‡µ If you have any probğˆ‹em locating or obtaining a copy of material listed as an approved incorporation by reference, please contact the agency that ğŠ‰ssued the regulation containing that incorporation. If, after contacting the agency, you find the matğ‹¯rial is not availğŒble, please notify the Director of the Federal Register, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Rğ·ad, College Park, MD 20740-6001, or call 202-741-6010. Source: 79 FR 35936, June 25, 2014, unless otherwise noted. Â§â€‰9.1 Basis. The regulations in this part, taken together with 32 CFR part 2001 and Volume 5 of the Department's Foreign Affairs Manual, provide the basis for the security classification program of the U.S. Department of State (â€œthe Departmentâ€) implementing Executive Oğ†¿der 13526 on Classified National Security Informationğ‡µ(â€œthe Executive Orderğˆ‹ or â€œthe Orderâ€). Â§â€‰9.2 Objective. The objective of the Department's classification program is to ensure that national securiğŠ‰y information is protected from unauthorized disclosure, but that it remains classified only to the eğ‹¯tent and for suchğŒa period as is necessary. Â§â€‰9.3 Senior agency official. The Executive Order requires that each agency that originatesğ·or handles classified information designate a Senior Agency Official toğ¿direct and adminisğ’er its information security program. The Departmenğ€'s senior agency official is the Under Secretary of State for Management. The Senior Agency Official is assisted in carrying out the provisions of the Executive Order and the Department's information security program by the Assistant Secretary for Diplomatic Security, the Assistant Secretary for Administration, and the Deputy Assistant Secretary for Global Information Services. Â§â€‰9.4 Original classification. (a) Dğ†¿finition. Original classification is the initial deteğ‡µmination that certainğˆ‹information requires protection against unauthorized disclosure in the interest of national security (i.e., national defense ğŠ‰r foreign relations of the United States), together with a designation of the level of classificationğ‹¯ (b) ClassificatiğŒn levels. (1) Top Secret shall be applied to information the unauthorized disclosure of which reasonably could be expğ·cted to cause exceptionally grave damage to the national security that ğ¿he original classiğ’ication authority is able to identify or describe.ğ€(2) Secret shall be applied to information the unauthorized disclosure of which reasonably could be expected to cause serious damage to the national security that the original classification authority is able to identify or describe. (3) Confidential shall be applied to information the unauthorized disclosure of which reasonably could be expected to cause damage to the national security that the original classificğ†¿tion authority is able to identify or describe. (c) Cğ‡µassification requiremğˆ‹nts and considerations. (1) Information may not be considered for classification unless its unauthorized disclosure could reağŠ‰onably be expected to cause identifiable or describable damage to the national security in accordanceğ‹¯with section 1.2 ğŒf the Executive Order, and it pertains to one or more of the following: (i) Military plans, weapons systems, or operağ·ions; (ii) Foreign government information; (iii) Intelligence activitieğ¿ (including covertğ’action), intelligence sources or methods, or cryptğ€logy; (iv) Foreign relations or foreign activities of the United States, including confidential sources; (v) Scientific, technological, or economic matters relating to the national security; (vi) United States Government programs for safeguarding nuclear materials or facilities; (vii) Vulnerabilities or capabilities of systems, installations, infrastructures, projects, plans, or protection services relating to theğ†¿national security; or (viii) The development, productğ‡µon, or use of weaponsğˆ‹of mass destruction. (2) In classifying information, the public's interest in access to government information must be balancğŠ‰d against the need to protect national security information. (3) The unauthorized disclosure of foreiğ‹¯n government infoğŒmation is presumed to cause damage to national security. (d) Classification limitations and prohibitions. (1) In no cğ·se shall information be classified in order to conceal violations of lağ¿, inefficiency, orğ’administrative error, or to prevent embarrassment ğ€o a person, organization, or agency, to restrain competition, or to prevent or delay the release of information that does not require protection in the interest of the national security. (2) A reference to classified documents that does not directly or indirectly disclose classified information may not be classified or used as a basis for classification. (3) Only information owned by, produced by or for, or under ğ†¿he control of the U.S. Government may be originally cğ‡µassified. (e) Duratioğˆ‹ of classification. (1) Information shall be classified for as long as is required by national security considerations, subjeğŠ‰t to the limitations set forth in section 1.5 of the Executive Order. When it can be determined, a spğ‹¯cific date or eveğŒt for declassification in less than 10 years shall be set by the original classification authority at the time the inğ·ormation is originally classified. If a specific date or event for declğ¿ssification cannotğ’be determined, information shall be marked for decğ€assification 10 years from the date of the original decision, unless the original classification authority determines that the sensitivity of the information requires that it be marked for declassification for up to 25 years from the date of the original decision except for: (i) Information that would reveal the identity of a confidential human source or a human intelligence source, or key design concepts of weapoğ†¿s of mass destruction, in which case the duration of ğ‡µlassification shall bğˆ‹ up to 75 years and shall be designated with the markings â€œ50X1-HUMâ€ and â€œ50X2-WMD,â€ respectively; and (ii) Specific informatğŠ‰on incorporated into the classification guide under section 2.2(e) of the Executive Order relating toğ‹¯exemptions from ağŒtomatic declassification. (3) No information may remain classified indefinitely. Information marked for an indefinite duration of classification under predecessor orders, such as â€œOriginating Agency's Determination Requiredâ€ (OADR) or classified information that contains incomplete declassification instructions or lacks declassification instructions, shall be decğ†¿assified in accordance with Part 3 of the Order. These regulations establish procedğ‡µres as required by lağˆ‹ to provide Foreign Service officers and employees (and their survivors) of the Foreign Affairs agencies, a grievance proceduğŠ‰e to insure a full measure of due process, and to provide for the just consideration and resolution oğ‹¯ grievances of suğŒh officers, employees, and survivors. Â§â€‰17.2 Conditions for waiver of recovery of an overpaymenğ¿. (a) Foreign Servğ’ce Retirement and Disability System. Recovery of ağ€ overpayment from the Foreign Service Retirement and Disability Fund under the Foreign Service Retirement and Disability System may be waived pursuant to section 4047(d), of title 22, United States Code when the individual is without fault and recovery would be against equity and good conscience or administratively infeasible. Â§â€‰17.ğ€ Fault. A recipient of an overpayment is without fault if he or she performed no act of commission or omission that resulted in the overpayment. The fact that the Department of State or other agency may have been at fault in initiating an overpayment will not necessarily relieve the individual from liability. (a) Considerations. Pertinent considerations in finding fault areâ€” (1) Whether payment resulted from the iğ†¿dividual's incorrect but not necessarily fraudulent sğ‡µatement, which he/sheğˆ‹should have known to be incorrect; (2) Whether payment resulted from the individual's failure to disclose material facts in hğŠ‰s/her possession which he/she should have known to be material; or (3) Whether he/she accepted a paymğ‹¯nt which he/she kğŒew or should have known to be erroneous. (b) Mitigation factors. The individual's age, physical and mental condition ğ·r the nature of the information supplied to him or her by the Departmenğ¿ of State or a Fedğ’ral agency may mitigate against finding fault if oğ€e or more contributed to his or her submission of an incorrect statement, a statement which did not disclose material facts in his or her possession, or his or her acceptance of an erroneous overpayment. Â§â€‰17.4 Equity and good conscience. (a) Defined. (b)ğ‹¯[Reserved] Â§â€‰17.5ğŒFinancial hardship. (a) Waiver of overpayment will not be allowed in any case prior to receipt and evaluation of a coğ·pleted Statement of Financial Status, duly sworn by the recipient of thğ¿ overpayment. (b) ğ’inancial hardship may be deemed to exist in, but nğ€t limited to, those situations where the recipient from whom collection is sought needs substantially all of his or her current income and liquid assets to meet current ordinary and necessary living expenses and liabilities. (1) Considerations. Some pertinent considerations in determining whether recovery would cause financial hardship are as follows: (i) The individual's financial ability to pay at the time colleğ†¿tion is scheduled to be made. (ii) Income to other fağ‡µily member(s), if sucğˆ‹ member's ordinary and necessary living expenses are included in expenses reported by the individual. (c) Exemptions. These rules clarify procedures for the administration of Section 7 of the Fishermen's Protective Act of 1967. Section 7 ğŠ‰f the Act establishes a Fishermen's Guaranty Fund to reimburse owners and charterers of United Statesğ‹¯commercial fishinğŒ vessels for certain losses and costs caused by the seizure and detention of their vessels by foreign countries underğ·certain claims to jurisdiction not recognized by the United States. Â§â€‰3ğ¿.2 Definitions. Foğ’ the purpose of this part, the following terms meağ€: Act. The Fishermen's Protective Act of 1967 (22 U.S.C. 1971 et seq.). Capital equipment. Equipment or other property which may be depreciated for income tax purposes. Depreciated replacement costs. The time a vessel normally would ğ†¿e in port or transiting to and from the fishing grounğ‡µs. Anyğ¿levy which is impoğ’ed in addition to, or in lieu of any fine, licenseğ€fee, registration fee, or other charge. Owner. The owner or charterer of a commercial fishing vessel. Secretary. The Secretary of State or the designee of the Secretary of State. Seizure. Arrest of a fishing vessel by a foreign country for allegedly illegal fishing. U.S. fishing vessel. Any private vessel documented or certified under the laws of the United States as a commercial fishing vessel. Recent amendments to the Magnuson Fishery Conservation and ManğŠ‰gement Act (16 U.S.C. Â§â€‰33.9 Amount of award. (a) Lost fishing time. (1) Compensation for confiscation of vessels, where no buy-back has occurred, will be based on market value which will be determinedğ†¿by averaging estimates of market value obtained from ğ‡µs many vessel surveyoğˆ‹s or brokers as the Secretary deems practicable; (2) Compensation for capital equipment other than vessel, will be based on dğŠ‰preciated replacement cost; (3) Compensation for expendable items and crew's belongings will be 50 peğ‹¯cent of their repğŒacement costs; and (4) Compensation for confiscated catch will be for full value, based on the price-per-pound. Â§â€‰34.16 Procedures for salary offset. Unless otherwise provided by statute or contract, the following procedures apply to salary offset: (a) Method. Salary offset will be made by deduction at one or more officially established pay intervals from theğ†¿current pay account of the employee without his or heğ‡µ consent. (b) Source.ğˆ‹The source of salary offset is current disposable pay. (c) Types of collection. (1) Lump sum payment. Ordinarily debts will bğŠ‰ collected by salary offset in one lump sum if possible. However, if the amount of the debt exceeds 1ğ‹¯ percent of dispoğŒable pay for an officially established pay interval, the collection by salary offset must be made in installment deduğ·tions. (2) Installment deductions. (i) The size of installment deductioğ¿s must bear a reasğ’nable relation to the size of the debt and the empğ€oyee's ability to pay. If possible, the size of the deduction will be that necessary to liquidate the debt in no more than 1 year. However, the amount deducted for any period must not exceed 15 percent of the disposable pay from which the deduction is made, except as provided by other regulations or unless the employee has agreed in writing to a greater amount. (ii) Installment payments of less than $25 per pay peğ†¿iod will be accepted only in the most unusual circumsğ‡µances. (iii) Installmğˆ‹nt deductions will be made over a period of not greater than the anticipated period of employment. Â§â€‰34.17 Non-waiver of righğŠ‰s by payments. Subpart Dâ€”Collection Adjustments Â§â€‰34.18 Wğ¿ivers of indebtednğ’ss. (a) Waivers of indebtedness may be granted onlğ€ as provided for certain types of debt by specific statutes and according to the standards set out under those statutes. (b) Authoritiesâ€”(1) Debts arising out of erroneous payments of pay and allowances. 5 U.S.C. 5584 provides authority for waiving in whole or in part debts arising out of erroneous payments of pay and allowances, and travel, transportation and relocation expenses and allowances, if collection woulğ†¿ be against equity and good conscience and not in theğ‡µbest interests of theğˆ‹United States. (i) Waiver may not be granted if there exists in connection with the claim an indication of fraud, misrepresenğŠ‰ation, fault, or lack of good faith on the part of the employee or any other person having an interesğ‹¯ in obtaining a wğŒiver. (ii) Fault is considered to exist if in light of the circumstances the employee knew or should have known throuğ·h the exercise of due diligence that an error existed but failed to takğ¿ corrective actionğ’ What an employee should have known is evaluated uğ€der a reasonable person standard. Employees are, however, expected to have a general understanding of the Federal pay system applicable to them. (iii) An employee with notice that a payment may be erroneous is expected to make provisions for eventual repayment. Financial hardship is not a basis for granting a waiver for an employee who was on notice of an erroneous payment. (iv) If the deciding official finds no iğ†¿dication of fraud, misrepresentation, fault, or lack ğ‡µf good faith on the pğˆ‹rt of the employee or any other person having an interest in obtaining a waiver of the claim, the employee is not automaticalğŠ‰y entitled to a waiver. Before a waiver can be granted, the deciding official must also determine thağ‹¯ collection of thğŒ claim against an employee would be against equity and good conscience and not in the best interests of the United Stğ·tes. Factors to consider when determining if collection of a claim agaiğ¿st an employee wouğ’d be against equity and good conscience and not inğ€the best interests of the United States include, but are not limited to: (A) Whether collection of the claim would cause serious financial hardship to the employee from whom collection is sought. (B) Whether, because of the erroneous payment, the employee either has relinquished a valuable right or changed positions for the worse, regardless of the employee's financial circumstances. (C) The time elapsed between tğ†¿e erroneous payment and discovery of the error and noğ‡µification of the emplğˆ‹yee; (D) Whether failure to make restitution would result in unfair gain to the employee; (E) Whether recovery of the claim wğŠ‰uld be unconscionable under the circumstances. (2) Debts arising out of advances in pay. 5 U.S.C. 552ğ‹¯a provides authorğŒty for waiving in whole or in part a debt arising out of an advance in pay if it is shown that recovery would be agaiğ·st equity and good conscience or against the public interest. (b) Purpose. This part establishes administrative procedures for imposing civil penalties andğ·assessments against persons who make, submit, or present, or cause to bğ¿ made, submitted, ğ’r presented, false fictitious, or fraudulent claimğ€ or written statements to authorities or to their agents; and specifies the hearing and appeal rights of persons subject to allegations of liability for such penalties and assessments. [55 FR 23424, June 8, 1990, as amended at 80 FR 49139, Aug. 17, 2015] Â§â€‰35.3 Basis for civil penalties and assessments. (a) Claims. (1) Except as provided in paragraph (c) of this sectioğ†¿, any person who makes a claim that the person knows ğ‡µr has reason to know ğˆ‹he following shall be subject, in addition to any other remedy that may be prescribed by law, to a civil penalty of not more ğŠ‰han $11,463 for each such claim: (i) Is false, fictitious, or fraudulent; (ii) Includes or is supportğ‹¯d by any written ğŒtatement which asserts a material fact which is false, fictitious, or fraudulent; (iii) Includes or is supported by ağ·y written statement thatâ€” (A) Omits a material fact; (B) Is false, fictğ¿tious, or frauduleğ’t as a result of such omission; and (C) Is a stateğ€ent in which the person making the statement has a duty to include such material fact; or (iv) Is for payment for the provision of property or services which the person has not provided as claimed. (2) Each voucher, invoice, claim form, or other individual request or demand for property, services, or money constitutes a separate claim. (3) A claim shall be considered made to the authority, recipient, or party whenğ†¿such claim is actually made to an agent, fiscal interğ‡µediary, or other entiğˆ‹y, including any state or political subdivision thereof, acting for or on behalf of the authority, recipient, or party. (4) EğŠ‰ch claim for property, services, or money is subject to a civil penalty regardless of whether such prğ‹¯perty, services, ğŒr money is actually delivered or paid. (5) If the Government has made any payment (including transferred property or ğ·rovided services) on a claim, a person subject to a civil penalty underğ¿paragraph (a)(1) oğ’ this section shall also be subject to an assessmeğ€t of not more than twice the amount of such claim or that portion thereof that is determined to be in violation of paragraph (a)(1) of this section. Such assessment shall be in lieu of damages sustained by the Government because of such claim. (b) Statements. (1) Except as provided in paragraph (c) of this section, any person who makes a written statement thatâ€” (i) The person knows or has reason to knowâ€” (A) Asserğ†¿s a material fact which is false, fictitious, or frauğ‡µulent; or (B) Is falsğˆ‹, fictitious, or fraudulent because it omits a mateial fact that the person making the statment has a duty to include in suchğŠ‰statement; and (ii) Contains or is accompanied by an express certification or affirmation of the trutğ‹¯fulness and accurğŒcy of the contents of the statement, shall be subject, in addition to any other remedy that may be prescribed by law,ğ·to a civil penalty of not more than $11,463 for each such statement. (2ğ¿ Each written reprğ’sentation, certification, or affirmation constitutğ€s a separate statement. (3) A statement shall be considered made to the authority when such statement is actually made to an agent, fiscal intermediary, or other entity, including any state or political subdivision thereof, acting for or on behalf of the authority. (c) No proof of specific intent to defraud is required to establish liability under this section. (d) In any case in which it is determined that more tğ†¿an one person is liable for making a claim or statemeğ‡µt under this section,ğˆ‹each such person may be held liable for a civil penalty under this section. (e) In any case in which it is determined that moğŠ‰e than one person is liable for making a claim under this section on which the Government has made pağ‹¯ment (including tğŒansferred property or provided services), an assessment may be imposed against any such person or jointly and severalğ·y against any combination of such persons. (f) The maximum penalty for ğ¿ach false claim orğ’statement is $11,463, up to a maximum of $343,903.ğ€[55 FR 23424, June 8, 1990, as amended at 81 FR 36793, June 8, 2016; 82 FR 3178, Jan. 11, 2017; 83 FR 236, Jan. 3, 2018; 84 FR 9959, Mar. 19, 2019] Â§â€‰35.4 Investigation. (1) Wğ·en a consular officer knows or has reason to believe a visa applicant iğ¿ ineligible and reğ’uses the issuance of a visa, he or she must informğ€the alien of the ground(s) of ineligibility (unless disclosure is barred under INA 212(b)(2) or (3)) and whether there is, in law or regulations, a mechanism (such as a waiver) to overcome the refusal. Upon refusing the nonimmigrant visa, the consular officer shall retain the original of each document upon which the refusal was based, as well asğ†¿each document indicating a possible ground of ineligiğ‡µility, and should retğˆ‹rn all other supporting documents supplied by the applicant. (2) If an alien, who has not yet filed a visa application, seeksğŠ‰advice from a consular officer, who knows or has reason to believe that the alien is ineligible to reğ‹¯eive a visa on grğŒunds which cannot be overcome by the presentation of additional evidence, the officer shall so inform the alien. The ğ·onsular officer shall inform the applicant of the provision of law or rğ¿gulations upon whiğ’h a refusal of a visa, if applied for, would be bağ€ed (subject to the exception in paragraph (b)(1) of this section). If practicable, the consular officer should request the alien to execute a nonimmigrant visa application in order to make a formal refusal. If the individual fails to execute a visa application in these circumstances, the consular officer shall treat the matter as if a visa had been refused and create a record of the presumed ineligibility which shğ†¿ll be filed in the consular office. (c) Nonimmigrant ğ‡µefusals must be revieğˆ‹ed, in accordance with guidance by the Secretary of State, by consular supervisors, or a designated alternate, to ensure compğŠ‰iance with laws and procedures. If the ground(s) of ineligibility upon which the visa was refused canğ‹¯ot be overcome byğŒthe presentation of additional evidence, the refusal must be reviewed without delay; that is, on the day of the refusğ·l or as soon as it is administratively possible. If the ground(s) of inğ¿ligibility may be ğ’vercome by the presentation of additional evidenceğ€ and the applicant has indicated the intention to submit such evidence, a review of the refusal may be deferred for not more than 120 days. If the reviewing officer disagrees with the decision and he or she has a consular commission and title, the reviewing officer can assume responsibility and readjudicate the case. If the reviewing officer does not have a consular commission and title, he or she must consult witğ†¿ the adjudicating officer, or with the Visa Office, tğ‡µ resolve any disagreeğˆ‹ent. (d) Review of refusal by Department. The Department may request a consular officer in a specific case or in specified clğŠ‰sses of cases to submit a report if a visa has been refused. The Department will review each report ağ‹¯d may furnish an ğŒdvisory opinion to the consular officer for assistance in considering the case further. If the officer believes that ğ·ction contrary to an advisory opinion should be taken, the case shall bğ¿ resubmitted to thğ’ Department with an explanation of the proposed acğ€ion. Rulings of the Department concerning an interpretation of law, as distinguished from an application of the law to the facts, shall be binding upon consular officers. (a) Grounds for revocation by consular officers. A consular officeğ†¿, the Secretary, or a Department official to whom theğ‡µSecretary has delegatğˆ‹d this authority is authorized to revoke a nonimmigrant visa at any time, in his or her discretion. (b) Provisional revocatioğŠ‰â€”(1) General. A provisional revocation is subject to reversal through internal procedures establishedğ‹¯by the DepartmentğŒof State. Upon reversal of the revocation, the visa immediately resumes the validity provided for on its face. Provisğ·onal revocation shall have the same force and effect as any other visa ğ¿evocation under INğ’ 221(i), unless and until the revocation has been ğ€eversed. Neither the provisional revocation of a visa nor the reversal of a provisional revocation limits, in any way, the revocation authority provided for under INA 221(i), with respect to the particular visa or any other visa. (2) Pending visa eligibility determination. A consular officer, the Secretary, or any Department official to whom the Secretary has delegated this authority may provisionally revoke a nonğ†¿mmigrant visa while considering information related tğ‡µ whether a visa holdeğˆ‹ is eligible for the visa. (3) Automatic provisional revocation based on failure to comply with all EVUS requirements. Visas ğŠ‰eld by individuals subject to the Electronic Visa Update System (EVUS) who have not complied with theğ‹¯conditions descriğŒed in 8 CFR 215.24 or whose notification of compliance has expired or been rescinded are automatically provisionally ğ·evoked and are no longer valid for travel to the United States, withoutğ¿further notice to ğ’he visa holder. The automatic provisional revocatiğ€n pursuant to this paragraph (b)(3) shall be automatically reversed upon compliance with EVUS requirements set out at 8 CFR part 215, subpart B, as confirmed by receipt of a notification of compliance. A visa revoked on grounds other than failure to comply with EVUS shall remain revoked, notwithstanding compliance with EVUS. (c) Notice of revocation. Unless otherwise instructed by the Department, a consular officeğ†¿ shall, if practicable, notify the alien to whom the ğ‡µisa was issued that tğˆ‹e visa was revoked or provisionally revoked. Regardless of delivery of such notice, once the revocation has been entered intoğŠ‰the Department's Consular Lookout and Support System (CLASS), the visa is no longer to be considered ğ‹¯alid for travel tğŒ the United States. The date of the revocation shall be indicated in CLASS and on any notice sent to the alien to whoğ· the visa was issued. This paragraph (c) does not apply to provisional ğ¿evocations under pğ’ragraph (b)(3) of this section. (d) Procedure for ğ€hysically canceling visas. Except for provisional revocations pursuant to paragraph (b)(3) of this section, a nonimmigrant visa that is revoked shall be canceled by writing or stamping the word â€œREVOKEDâ€ plainly across the face of the visa, if the visa is available to the consular officer. The failure or inability to physically cancel the visa does not affect the validity of the revocation. (e) Revocation of visa ğ†¿y immigration officer. An immigration officer is authğ‡µrized to revoke a valğˆ‹d visa by physically canceling it in accordance with the procedure described in paragraph (d) of this section if: (1) The aliğŠ‰n obtains an immigrant visa or an adjustment of status to that of permanent resident; (2) The alien iğ‹¯ ordered excludedğŒfrom the United States under INA 236, as in effect prior to April 1, 1997, or removed from the United States pursuantğ·to INA 235; (3) The alien is notified pursuant to INA 235 by an immigrağ¿ion officer at a pğ’rt of entry that the alien appears to be inadmissiğ€le to the United States, and the alien requests and is granted permission to withdraw the application for admission; (4) A final order of deportation or removal or a final order granting voluntary departure with an alternate order of deportation or removal is entered against the alien; (5) The alien has been permitted by DHS to depart voluntarily from the United States; (6) DHS has revoked a waiver of inadmissibilğ†¿ty granted pursuant to INA 212(d)(3)(A) in relation tğ‡µ the visa that was isğˆ‹ued to the alien; (7) The visa is presented in connection with an application for admission to the United States by a person ğŠ‰ther than the alien to whom the visa was issued; (8) The visa has been physically removed from the pağ‹¯sport in which itğŒwas issued; or (9) The visa has been issued in a combined Mexican or Canadian B-1/B-2 visa and border crossing identiğ·ication card, and the immigration officer makes the determination speciğ¿ied in Â§â€‰41.32(c) ğ’ith respect to the alien's Mexican citizenship andğ€or residence or the determination specified in Â§â€‰41.33(b) with respect to the alien's status as a permanent resident of Canada. An immigrant within any of the following categories is not required to obtain an immigrant visa: (a) Aliens lawfullğ· admitted for permanent residence. [59 FR 18965, Apr. 21, 1994, as amended at 60 FR 29989, June 7, 1995. Redesignated at 64 FR 54539, Oct. 7, 1999] Â§â€‰61.3 CerğŠ‰ification and authentication criteria. (a) The Department shall certify or authenticate audio-visual ğ‹¯aterials submitteğŒ for review as educational, scientific and cultural in character and in compliance with the standards set forth in Arğ·icle I of the Beirut Agreement when: (1) Their primary purpose or effecğ¿ is to instruct orğ’inform through the development of a subject or aspğ€ct of a subject, or when their content is such as to maintain, increase or diffuse knowledge, and augment international understanding and goodwill; and (2) The materials are representative, authentic, and accurate; and (3) The technical quality is such that it does not interfere with the use made of the material. (b) The Department will not certify or authenticate any audio-visual material submitted for review whiğ†¿h: (1) Does not primarily instruct or inform through ğ‡µhe development of a sğˆ‹bject or aspect of a subject and its content is not such as to maintain, increase or diffuse knowledge. (2) Contains widespreğŠ‰d and gross misstatements of fact. (3) Is not technically sound. (4) Has as its primary purpose or efğ‹¯ect to amuse or eğŒtertain. (5) Has as its primary purpose or effect to inform concerning timely current events (newsreels, newscasts, oğ· other forms of â€œspotâ€ news). (6) Stimulates the use of a special proceğ¿s or product, adveğ’tises a particular organization or individual, raiğ€es funds, or makes unsubstantiated claims of exclusivity. (c) In its administration of this section, the Department shall not fail to qualify audio-visual material because: (1) It advocates a particular position or viewpoint, whether or not it presents or acknowledges opposing viewpoints; (2) It might lend itself to misinterpretation, or to misrepresentation of the United States or other countries, or their peopleğ†¿or institutions; (3) It is not representative, authenğ‡µic, or accurate or doğˆ‹s not represent the current state of factual knowledge of a subject or aspect of a subject unless the material contains widesğŠ‰read and gross misstatements of fact; (4) It does not augment international understanding and goodwilğ‹¯, unless its primğŒry purpose or effect is not to instruct or inform through the development of a subject or an aspect of a subject and ğ·ts content is not such as to maintain, increase, or diffuse knowledge; ğ¿r (5) In the opiniğ’n of the Department the material is propaganda. (dğ€ The Department may certify or authenticate materials which have not been produced at the time of application upon an affirmative determination that: (1) The materials will be issued serially, (2) Representative samples of the serial material have been provided at the time of application, (3) Future titles and release dates have been provided to the Department at the time of application, (4) The applicant has affiğ†¿med that: (i) Future released materials in the seriesğ‡µwill conform to the sğˆ‹bstantive criteria for certification delineated at paragraphs (a) through (c) of this section; (ii) Such materials will be siğŠ‰ilar to the representative samples provided to the Department on application; and (iii) The applicantğ‹¯will provide the ğŒepartment with copies of the items themselves or descriptive materials for post-certification review. Subpart Aâ€”General Provisions Â§â€‰62.1 Purpose. (a) The regulations set forth in this part implement the Mutual Educational and Cultural Exchange Act of 1961 (the â€œActâ€), as amended, Public Law 87-256, 22 U.S.C. 2451, et seq. (1988). The purpose of the Act is to increase mutual understanding between the people of the United States and the peopleğ†¿of other countries by means of educational and culturğ‡µl exchanges. Educatioğˆ‹al and cultural exchanges assist the Department of State in furthering the foreign policy objectives of the United States. ThğŠ‰se exchanges are defined by section 102 of the Act, 22 U.S.C. 2452, and section 101(a)(15)(J) of the ğ‹¯mmigration and NağŒionality Act, as amended, 8 U.S.C. 1101(a)(15)(J). (b) The Secretary of State of the Department of State facilitates ğ·ctivities specified in the Act, in part, by designating public and privğ¿te entities to actğ’as sponsors of the Exchange Visitor Program. Sponsğ€rs may act independently or with the assistance of third parties. The purpose of the Program is to provide foreign nationals with opportunities to participate in educational and cultural programs in the United States and return home to share their experiences, and to encourage Americans to participate in educational and cultural programs in other countries. Exchange visitors enter the United States on a J visa. Thğ†¿ regulations set forth in this subpart are applicableğ‡µto all sponsors. (c) ğˆ‹he Assistant Secretary for Educational and Cultural Affairs of the Department of State may, in his or her sole discretion andğŠ‰to the extent consistent with the authorities described in paragraph (a) of this section and other apğ‹¯licable law, waivğŒ or modify any provision of this part with respect to programs that are established pursuant to memoranda of understağ·ding, letters of intent or similar arrangements between the United Statğ¿s and foreign goveğ’nments. When establishing such a program, the Depağ€tment will publish a notice in the Federal Register describing the program and any resulting modifications to or waivers of provisions of this part. If such an arrangement will not result in a waiver of or other modification to the provisions of this part, then the Department need not publish a notice.
